Stocks rallied hard yesterday - sending the S&P up 1.8% just enough to nearly 'kiss' it's 200 dma at 2060...... .....ignited by commentary supplied by none other than Santa Claus - otherwise known as the European Central Bank (ECB) President Uncle Mario (Draghi). Yesterday morning - Draghi 'hinted' (wink, wink) that he was prepared once again to 'do more to boost…

Ok...so what happened last night? All that hype about the China macro data kept everyone on edge over the weekend...what would they report? Would it be a disaster? What would that say about the health of the Chinese economy and then by default the global economy? In the end - it was NOT a blockbuster, in fact it was rather boring really....

At 10:00 pm est - China released a bunch of data - and it was mixed.....no disasters but no upside surprises either.........3rd Qtr GDP came in above expectations at 6.9% (exp was for 6.8%), Industrial Production did rise 5.7%, but that was below the exp of 6%. Fixed Asset Investments (FAI) - a key reading - came in at 10.3% - below the expectation of 10.8% and Retail Sales - that beat at 10.9% vs. the exp of 10.8%... So what does it all mean? Well - to start with - the data implies that the world is not ending and that the Chinese economy appears to be stabilizing - which in the end is a positive.
Angus Nicholson - Market Analyst at IG sums it up like this:

"It's hard to be overly optimistic about the headline number, especially given the range of other data released today. Nonetheless, markets have clearly been buoyed by the better than expected headline number, and it shows that China's economy has not deteriorated as much as some had thought"
James Laurenceson - Deputy Director of the Australia-China Relations Institute added that:

"The data show a rebalancing away from growth driven by investment and secondary sector production towards consumption and the services sector. It's time we accept that Chinese growth isn't solely at the mercy of industrial production and fixed asset investment"

So maybe, just maybe this is the 'new normal' for China. Maybe the world will see a China growing at a 6 handle and that's ok. Analysts are already looking out to the 4th qtr and suspect that by year end China will achieve annual growth of 6.8% -7% on continued fiscal and monetary support.

Global markets are not panicking with on these reports. In fact - there appears to be a little bit of 'risk on' as the investors/traders are relieved that the data was NOT as bad as analysts had prepared us for. Asian markets essentially ended flat. Japan - the worst performer - ended the day -0.88%, Hong Kong + 0.04%, China + 0.14% and ASX +0.03%.
European markets are also higher - discounting the China data and refocusing on earnings. FTSE flat, CAC 40 +0.32%, DAX + 0.86%, EUROSTOXX + 0.53%, SPAIN flat, and ITALY + 0.61%.

France's Danone Group up 2.5% beat estimates, Germany's Deutsche Bank +3.1%, announces a big management shakeup and restructuring plan - heads to roll and that is helping to send other financials higher. German retailer Metro - announces a rise in sales and is talking all bullish about the coming Christmas season sending this stock up by 3.7%. Air France- KLM announces job CUTS in 2016 and investors love it - sending that stock higher.... and not to be left in the dark - Italian carmaker Ferrari is getting ready to price its IPO tomorrow and will start trading on the NYSE on Thursday.

This morning US futures are off 1 pt.....Now prior to the China report - US futures were pointing lower on the expectation that we were gonna get hit hard....and when that did not happen - Futures moved to the plus side and are now flat. I suspect that the market will test resistance at 2040 and then back off trying to find support in the 2025 range - if not, then definitely the 1980 range.

As much as there is plenty of US macro data this week - the focus will now return to US corp earnings. This week and next week will see hundreds of reports for investors to chew on. Earnings to include: HAS, MS, HAL, GPC, IBM, ZION, AXP, BA, KO, MCD, MSFT, and PG to name just a few.
NOTE: Fed's Lacker is due to speak today at 12 pm.

Up til now - earnings have been, well, not so good. Not horrible, but not great. 70% are beating the estimates while only 48% of those are beating on top line revenue growth. Despite the economic weakness and a bunch of downgrades - stocks have not done so badly.....with the DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all closing close to 2 month highs.... All of these indexes have now pierced their down trending 50 dma's and are now challenging their intermediate term resistance - or 100 dma's. Now here we may hit some trouble - but I think that is just a matter of time....unless earnings completely implode - then I suspect that we will test resistance one or two more times before 'breaking out' and challenging the longer term resistance levels defined by their 200 dma's. And as is usual - as we move thru the 4th qtr - FOMO (fear of missing out) will help to lift stocks going into year end.

Now on the other hand - small caps are lagging...... The most recent lows for small caps came early October and it was much lower than the August 24th sell-off lows. The most recent highs were just two weeks ago and those highs were lower than the highs set in mid-September. - suggesting that a bearish downtrend (lower lows and lower highs) remains intact from a small cap perspective. And why would this be so?

Well - it is earnings season, and it is more common for the large cap/mid cap companies to be able to borrow money to buy back shares which will serve to 'doll up" their earnings per share. (Small cap companies are not nearly as active buying back stock to create the illusion of better earnings and so you have the disconnect.) Or it could be that small caps are more risky and at a time of global nervousness - investors may want the security of large cap, liquid, dividend paying names....It's just a thought.....

The fact that small caps continue to lag might suggest that the selling pressure is not over yet....but until we get thru earnings season the divergence will continue. Then it will be Thanksgiving, and the debt debacle in DC, and then the FED December decision.... so there is plenty ahead to keep investors on their toes the question is: Does the market have enough strength to support another "Santa Clause" rally into the end of the year?
Take good care
Kp

"Words of War" - A special evening in support of comprehensive mental healthcare for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans will take place tonight - Monday, October 19th, 2015 - Freedom Tower - NYC.

The Headstrong Project - a veterans charitable organization begun by a returning Iraqi War Veteran - A US Marine - that not only saw but understood the impact that this war was going to have on a nation of Americans, will hold their 3rd Annual Fundraiser to help 'heal the hidden wounds of war'. In partnership with Weill Cornell Medical College - One of this nation's leading mental health care centers - The Headstrong Project has developed the first of its kind, comprehensive treatment program for veterans in need.

I am proud to be on the host committee and I am proud to participate as the evening's Live Auctioneer as we raise money to support the very men and women who answered the call. I am looking to break the record and raise $1 mil this evening and I could use your help. Please visit
Getheadstrong.org/words-of-war/
Getheadstrong.org/donate-support/
as we honor the men and women who fight valiantly for our freedom.

Tell the truth with your employees and customers, even if the news is bad. The gains over the long run far outweigh any short-term pain, as Bob Carr, CEO of Princeton, N.J.-based Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), has learned.

 Live up to values. Carr, who wrote the book "Through the Fires," dealt with his biggest crisis in 2009. A massive security breach compromised credit- and debit-card numbers for millions of transactions that Heartland processed.
Lawyers told Carr to say nothing beyond that a breach occurred.
"I couldn't figure out how to do that and still communicate honestly with our employees," Carr told IBD. "I couldn't play rope-a-dope."

He opened up to employees, customers and the market. The stock sank, but Heartland worked to strengthen security. The firm was upfront with information and drew plaudits from customers. Employees rallied around the company. It lost just 2% of its clients, quickly returned to Visa's (V) preferred list and the stock rebounded.

 Eye the long term. People can get away with deceptive business practices and shady dealings for a while. But eventually customers won't come back once they realize they've been duped. Employees will leave because they don't want to be part of the untruths. "It catches up to you eventually," Carr said.

 Stick to your guns. A Procter & Gamble (PG) subcontractor went dumpster-diving at rival Unilever's (UN) hair care headquarters in 2001 to steal that company's trade secrets. When P&G CEO John Pepper found out about it, he quickly told Unilever, fired the subcontractors, paid a settlement and made sure his company never used the information. He simply stuck to P&G's principles that he had lived by throughout his career. "That culture is a strong part of who they are," said Paul Fiorelli, co-director of the Cintas Institute for Business Ethics at Xavier University.

 Set the tone. The CEO needs to show he lives by the firm's principles at all times. He can't make exceptions for himself by cheating on expense reports. Other leaders also need to live up to the principles.
"If I'm not at the top, I take my cues from the boss, and maybe my boss' boss," Fiorelli said. "It's tone at the top, mood in the middle and buzz at the bottom."

 Stick to the basics. Carr learned from a young age the importance of doing the right thing. He especially took after his honest mother. "Things were black and white growing up," he said. "I saw that there are proper and ethical behaviors, and those that are not. It never occurred to me that I would treat people any way other than how I wanted to be treated."
 Take bad with good. When foul news arises, leaders need to be willing to hear about it and address it without blowing up. Otherwise, people won't report the bad.
Promote hotlines and a reporting process to encourage people to let on about the bad stuff. "If you want openness and candor, you have to accept that people will be open and candid," Fiorelli said.

 Be vigilant. Carr has gone on a crusade to clean up peer firms that act unethically. Hidden charges and processing bank transactions out of order to maximize fees were the norm. He has sued other companies. "The industry has paid attention," he said. "They realize, 'If Carr is going after them, he might come after us next.'"

 Stay consistent. Get rid of people who don't live by the principles. Make no exceptions, even if they're strong producers. "If you allow that, you're saying that making the numbers is all that counts," Fiorelli said. "Don't let high performers get away with things."Tell the truth with your employees and customers, even if the news is bad. The gains over the long run far outweigh any short-term pain, as Bob Carr, CEO of Princeton, N.J.-based Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), has learned. Live up to values. Shares of Kimberly-Clark (KMB) gapped up Tuesday to their highest level since January after the company reported forecast-topping first-quarter results and held to its full-year guidance despite what it called "substantial" currency weakness internationally.

The company, whose brands include Huggies, Kleenex and Depend adult diapers, said sales fell 4% to $4.691 billion, edging expectations for $4.611 billion. The shaky currency landscape outside the U.S. reduced sales by 9%.
Earnings per share fell 4% to 1.42, topping views by 11 cents.
The company also reaffirmed its full-year EPS guidance issued earlier of $5.60-$5.80, with the midpoint above Wall Street's consensus expectation of $5.64.

Kimberly-Clark shares rose 4.4% to 112.13 in the stock market today, nearly clearing away declines suffered after a steep drop below its 50-day line that began Jan. 26 and dug below the 200-day line in March. Both are key tests of investor support of a stock.
Despite the gap-up, the stock is still only about halfway toward clearing a flat base formed Jan. 22.

Sales fell 3% to $2.3 billion in the company's big personal-care segment, in no small part due to adverse currency rates. In North America, Huggies diaper volumes fell in the "mid-single digits," a drop the company blamed on "lower market shares and competitive promotion activity."
As the Wall Street Journal noted Tuesday, the slide in sales comes amid a bigger battle for the best diaper that has threatened Kimberly-Clark's top-tier spot in the segment.

More parent shoppers are gravitating away from Huggies and buying either less expensive or premium diaper offerings, which include Procter & Gamble's (PG) cheaper Luvs and upscale Pampers offerings, the paper said, a trend that would echo a broader consumer preference for either high-end or value groceries. P&G, which got into the adult-diaper business last year to shore up middling sales, could also capture more market in that category, the Journal observed.
Kimberly-Clark said that sales fell 7% in its consumer tissue segment and 1% in its K-C Professional Segment.

Procter & Gamble shares rose 0.3% to 83.13.Shares of Kimberly-Clark (KMB) gapped up Tuesday to their highest level since January after the company reported forecast-topping first-quarter results and held to its full-year guidance despite what it called "substantial" currency weakness internationally.The company, whose brands include Huggies, Kleenex and Depend adult diapers, said sales fell 4% to $4.691 billion, edging expectations for $4.611 billion. The shaky currency landscape outside the U.S. reduced sales by 9%.Earnings per share fell 4% to 1.42, topping views by 11 cents.The company also reaffirmed its full-year EPS guidance issued earlier of $5.60-$5.80, with the midpoint above Wall Street's consensus expectation of $5.64.Kimberly-Clark shares rose 4.4% to 112.13 in the stock market today, nearly clearing away declines suffered after a steep drop below its 50-day line that began Jan. 26 and dug below the 200-day line in March. Both are key tests of investor support of a stock.Despite the gap-up, the stock is still only about halfway toward clearing a flat base formed Jan. 22.Sales fell 3% to $2.3 billion in the company's big personal-care segment, in no small part due to adverse currency rates. In North America, Huggies diaper volumes fell in the "mid-single digits," a drop the company blamed on "lower market shares and competitive promotion activity."As the Wall Street Journal noted Tuesday, the slide in sales comes amid a bigger battle for the best diaper that has threatened Kimberly-Clark's top-tier spot in the segment.More parent shoppers are gravitating away from Huggies and buying either less expensive or premium diaper offerings, which include Procter & Gamble's (PG) cheaper Luvs and upscale Pampers offerings, the paper said, a trend that would echo a broader consumer preference for either high-end or value groceries. P&G, which got into the adult-diaper business last year to shore up middling sales, could also capture more market in that category, the Journal observed.Kimberly-Clark said that sales fell 7% in its consumer tissue segment and 1% in its K-C Professional Segment.Procter & Gamble shares rose 0.3% to 83.13.

Owning well-established blue chips that generate slow but steady gains and dividends is one way to play the stock market.

But investors looking for a little more sizzle should be on the lookout for newer names with the potential for fast growth. Think of the N in CAN SLIM, which stands for new products, new management, new companies — and even new highs.

Big caps such as Coca-Cola (KO), General Electric (GE) and Procter & Gamble (PG), all components of the Dow Jones industrial average, have a long history and tend to provide fairly stable profits as well as an income stream. They also have market caps near $200 billion or higher, and have more than 2 billion shares outstanding.

What they don't usually offer, however, is a big run-up in stock price over a relatively short period. And most are cyclical — more subject to what's going on in the economy. The price performance this year for the three Dow stocks mentioned above ranges from -4% to a 9% gain. The overall Dow is up 7%.
By comparison, the Nasdaq composite, which tends to house newer, younger companies, has risen 13%. The S&P 500 is up 11%. So adding some newer stocks to your portfolio could help boost performance.
What's considered young?

IBD research has found that companies tend to make their biggest advance during the first several years after coming public. As a rule of thumb, a newer company is one that has been publicly traded for less than 15 years.

That's not to say an older company won't make a second big run. Most don't — but one exception is Apple (AAPL), 37 years old as a public company. The iPhone and iPad maker has had its share of ups and downs over the years, but has had a yet another revitalization: It's rallied over 40% this year.

New companies can create new markets, and those leaders can post enormous gains. Look at action camera maker GoPro (GPRO), up 200% from its June 26 debut. Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for GoPro cameras, has surged more than 730% since its October 2012 IPO.

More recently, a flurry of Chinese Internet stocks have surged amid the growth of the middle class in the Middle Kingdom. Alibaba (BABA), Baidu (BIDU) and BitAuto (BITA), which range from two months to nine years in age, have generated big gains for shareholders.

That's not to say you can pick any young stock and expect a big gain. Due diligence is necessary, as are the usual factors — the overall stock market, the economy, company fundamentals, and price and volume action. Also key: buying at the right time.

Mobileye (MBLY) formed an IPO base soon after its Aug. 1 debut. Investors who got in at the 41.60 buy point would have enjoyed a 41% gain in two weeks (1) — triggering the eight-week hold rule for fast movers.

The stock has now pulled back into a new base. Those who bought at the entry still hold a high single-digit percentage gain, but anyone chasing the stock on its way up would now have a smaller gain, if not a loss.

Mobileye's technology goes into camera-based advanced driver assistance systems. Its technology is used in cars by most major automakers, and is thought to be in some new Tesla Motors ' (TSLA) vehicles.Owning well-established blue chips that generate slow but steady gains and dividends is one way to play the stock market.But investors looking for a little more sizzle should be on the lookout for newer names with the potential for fast growth. Stocks weakened and were narrowly mixed late Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 0.2%, but Nasdaq lost 0.2%. Turnover was running lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today compared with the same time Monday.
The major averages have seesawed amid mixed economic data.

Some medical stocks were in comeback mode after being slammed Monday. Biogen (BIIB), Celgene (CELG) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) had gains ranging from a fraction to 3%. But AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), Universal Health Services (UHS) and Impax Laboratories (IPXL) lost between 3% and 9%.

Elsewhere, Chuy's (CHUY) eased but was still up about 3%. Shares of the restaurant operator were up nearly 4% after being started at outperform and given a price target of 32 from research firm Telsey Advisory Group.
Post Holdings (POST) dropped 7% to its lowest level since Aug. 7. On Monday, the stock had already tumbled 9% and triggered the 8% sell rule from a 67.50 entry in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Procter & Gamble has decided that less is more. The maker of Bounty, Pampers, Crest and Tide announced plans Friday to eliminate more than 100 brands globally over the next two years.The 70 to 80 brands being kept make up nearly 90% of Procter & Gamble's (PG) current sales and over 95% of current profit.P&G didn't say which products it was taking off shelves."Everything needs to begin with consumer value creation — and end with consumer satisfaction & loyalty," said CEO A.G. Lafley in a P&G tweet.Shares climbed 3% to 79.65, P&G's biggest single-day percentage gain since May 2013. The stock had fallen the prior five sessions, closing Thursday at its lowest level since mid-February.The Cincinnati-based company also said that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 20% vs. a year earlier to 95 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 91 cents.But sales fell 2.4% to $20.2 billion, below views for $20.5 billion. "We have more work to do to deliver the profitable sales growth and strong cash productivity we are capable of delivering," said Lafley in a statement.For fiscal 2015, P&G expects low-single-digit sales growth vs. Wall Street views for a 3.5% gain. It sees non-GAAP earnings increasing in the mid-single digits vs. the consensus for 7% growth.

Ron Weisner is used to having demanding clients.After all, he's a music manager.From the 1960s through the 1990s, he traveled the world with the likes of Michael Jackson ("obsessive perfectionist"), Paul McCartney ("zero ego") and Madonna ("never grateful")."The music business isn't normal on a good day," Weisner, author of "Listen Out Loud," told IBD. "Managing artists is like owning a chain of 7-Elevens — you're on call all the time and have to be there for one emergency after another. But I was fortunate in having clients who made timeless music."He got out of artist management 15 years ago. Now he organizes arena concerts for corporations featuring top artists such as Beyonce and the Eagles. He also produces specials for BET, MTV and VH1.Grow With The BeatWeisner, 69, grew up in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, N.Y., where during the summer everyone played music with the windows open, mixing Elvis with Jamaican calypso, Motown and the Four Tops.In his teens, he would sneak over to the Apollo Theater in Harlem to catch concerts by the likes of Aretha Franklin and Little Stevie Wonder, and was usually the only white kid in the audience."There's a whole generation of listeners who haven't experienced what it's like to see a tight, well-rehearsed band blow the roof off a theater, and it breaks my heart that today it's considered a successful show when the prerecorded vocal track to which the singer is lip-synching doesn't crap out in the middle of a song," Weisner wrote.In 1966 he got a job in the mailroom at MGM Records. He spent loads of time in the office of Harold Berkman, head of promotions, listening to how he pitched stations for new releases. Berkman decided to make Weisner his assistant.Weisner saw how singers did interviews with the press and noted that MGM's units worked closely together ("there were no divas").After a year with Berkman, Weisner shifted to marketing in the Verve label, where he learned about distribution, production quality control and the label's artist and repertoire segment, which was signing new acts like Richie Havens, Janis Ian and the Velvet Underground.In 1969, Weisner followed two colleagues from MGM to Buddah Records (later renamed Buddha)."We knew that to survive, we'd have to outhustle and outthink the major labels, but we thought we could develop a reputation for being more artist friendly," he said.One of Buddah's most important clients was Curtis Mayfield, who had composed many of the anthems of the civil rights movement."One of the great wordsmiths of our era," said Weisner.Mayfield and two other Buddah performers, Gladys Knight and Sha Na Na, became Weisner's first management clients."What I wanted to do was to nurture the best talent, helping them put on brilliant live shows and build a following over the long run," said Weisner, who moved his management business to Los Angeles in 1972."The first thing that grabbed me about Ron is how much he loved music," wrote Knight in the foreword to Weisner's memoir. "When I asked him to be my manager, he said, 'I'll do what I can.' He didn't talk a big game like some managers do. The passion and loyalty he has for his artists, his business associates and his friends are unmatched."Sha Na Na was a dozen guys who put on 250 shows a year, but each had a different idea of what the band should be doing.Weisner had to constantly intervene in their arguments while making their 1950s doo-wop style famous with their appearance in the 1978 movie "Grease."He also signed a syndication deal for a TV variety series for them, but it needed a sponsor. Weisner approached some Procter & Gamble (PG) executives, but they were skeptical about the group's appeal.Weisner came up with a flashy idea. He arranged for them to fly to New York so the P&G suits could see Sha Na Na perform, then called a billboard company. As the execs were driven up Sixth Avenue, the electronic billboards flashed pictures of the performers.P&G signed, and the show ran for four seasons.In 1977, Weisner got a call from a friend who said a group of brothers called the Jackson 5 needed help. They had left Motown for Epic Records, and their career had stalled because their light pop style had lost its appeal.The problem was that their dad and manager, Joe Jackson, didn't care what they sang, as long as he could squeeze every dollar out of the deal. They were petrified of him."I knew I was walking into a minefield and became their manager anyway," Weisner said. "Joe and I had constant fights, and my only real concern was that I could keep these away from Michael, who could make magic when he was in the studio."Feet On The GroundWeisner found Michael to be a serious student of entertainment who had studied how Fred Astaire, Charlie Chaplin and James Brown danced and moved."His energy level was off the charts, unmatched by anyone I've seen before or since," Weisner said. "He wanted to be the best, then go beyond that."Against the wishes of Epic, which thought Quincy Jones was too old to produce a record for what they thought was Michael's preteen audience, Weisner arranged for him to handle Jackson's solo record "Off the Wall."The process proved worth it.After it was released in 1979, "Off the Wall" sold 20 million copies — compared with the 1.3 million the label had expected.Jackson's next album, "Thriller," was the ultimate smash after coming out in 1982. It sold 110 million copies, the greatest number ever.Michael had been calling Weisner 20 times a day when suddenly he stopped in 1984, after Joe Jackson reasserted his control over his son's careers.Downs And UpsBy then, Weisner had brought on a partner, Freddy DeMann, but by 1985 they had different visions for the business and decided to divvy up the clients.One of those clients was Madonna, and Weisner happily let DeMann have her.The singer had topped the charts the year before, but her demeanor wasn't for Weisner."Sure I want to help my family have the good life, but I also want me to have a good life, and if Madonna were part of it, no amount of money was worth the headache," Weisner wrote.Paul McCartney sparked the opposite experience."He was, without fail, a joy to work with — professional, energized and punctual," Weisner wrote. "From him I learned that you must persevere not only when things are at their worst, but also when they're at their best. I learned that it's possible to balance your show business with your personal life and remain at the top of your game in both. I learned that entertainment is a noble profession."Larry Schweikart, director of the independent film "Rockin' the Wall," said: "In interviewing musicians for our documentary on how rock music helped bring down the Iron Curtain, I learned that almost all of them had a very difficult time finding a manager they could trust. Ron Weisner was known for having built his success on being absolutely honest and always putting the client's benefit before his own. That's a lesson that can be applied to any profession."

It was a tale of two markets Friday, as a sell-off in chip stocks fueled a precipitous decline in the Nasdaq. Blue chips, however, outperformed.With a little over one hour remaining in the session, the Nasdaq fell 1.1%. It was earlier down by as much as 1.8%. The S&P 500 eased 0.1% while the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Thursday's levels.Top-performing Dow components included Coca-Cola (KO) and Procter & Gamble (PG).The biggest decliners in the Nasdaq 100 all hailed from the chip sector. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shed 12% while Avago (AVGO) and Xilinx (XLNX) fell 9% and 7%, respectively.The chip sell-off was partly ignited by Microchip Technology (MCHP). Shares slumped 10.5% after the company pre-announced weaker-than-expected revenue for the current quarter.In the stock market today, IPO Dave & Busters (PLAY) debuted strongly in a shaky market. It priced last night at 16, at the low end of proposed range of 16-18. Shares of the arcade and restaurant chain were recently trading around 17.18.Elsewhere, Infosys (INFY) reclaimed a 62.26 cup-with-handle buy point after the IT services names reported solid earnings. Shares gapped up and rose 6%. It's still in a buy range but new buys are risky when the market's in a correction.Tesla Motors (TSLA) lost 7% after the company unveiled spruced up features at the rate the company requested.

Major averages were near session highs in late-afternoon trading Tuesday as the bulls regained control at least for a day. The Dow Jones industrial average added 1.4%, fueled by strong performances from Procter & Gamble (PG) and Merck (MRK). The S&P 500 rose 1.3% and the Nasdaq gained 1.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Monday's levels in the stock market today.

In economic news, retail sales took a pause in August, while the Empire State Manufacturing Survey missed expectations by a mile. It came in at -14.67, well below the consensus estimate of -0.5. Industrial production fell 0.4%, a little worse than the consensus estimate of -0.2%.

The soft data fueled at least some speculation that the Fed could leave rates unchanged when the meeting concludes Thursday. But money flowed out of bonds, lifting the yield on the 10-year Treasury note 8 basis points to 2.26%. Some committee members believe a rate hike is warranted, but others aren't so sure. According to CME Group FedWatch, the odds of a rate hike are 25%.
Among the day's gainers, PRA Health Sciences (PRAH) rose nearly 3% as it crafts a new base. It's closing in quickly on a 44.11 buy point.

Meanwhile, the IBD 50 dished up plenty of winners early Tuesday. Paycom Software (PAYC) jumped nearly 4%. It's still in a buy range from a 39.27 buy point. Paycom has been one of the more resilient growth names in the market recently.

Nasdaq 100 winners include Google (GOOGL), Priceline (PCLN) and Avago Technologies (AVGO), with gains of more than 2%. Google has been consolidating since July and recently found support at its 10-week moving average. Priceline is holding near highs and still in a buy range from a 1264.10 cup-with-handle buy point. Avago is back above its 10-week moving average as it works on the right side of possible new base.

Stock futures were slightly off highs, but still up sharply ahead of Tuesday's open, bolstered by strong overseas action. Dow futures were up 261 points, down from a 300-point gain an hour earlier. S&P 500 futures were 32 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a strong 77.2 points, also off earlier highs.

The stock market today is showing a bit of optimism before the open. Trade data in China on Tuesday showed the value of imports fell sharply, while exports slowed modestly in August, widening China's trade gap by nearly 40% vs. July to a near record $57.8 billion.
In Germany, the August trade deficit narrowed sharply as both imports and exports hit record highs.

China's markets slumped in early trade, then rallied late to finish with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 3.3% and the Shanghai Composite ahead 2.9%. China's weak economic data hit hard in Japan, where Tokyo's Nikkei 225 sloughed off 2.4%.
Europe's markets climbed sharply, with top indexes trading up more than 2% near mid-session.
The market receives only a small dose of economic news today, with the Federal Reserve releasing its August Labor Market Conditions Index at 10 a.m., and July consumer credit numbers at 3 p.m.
Leading the Dow stocks in premarket trade, Procter & Gamble (PG) rose more than 2%, American Express (AXP) was up 2%. All Dow issues were positive.
On the Nasdaq 100, JD.com (JD) plowed ahead more than 5% after the company announced it would buy back up to $1 billion in American Depositary shares in the next 24 months.
Vodafone (VOD) and Micron Technology (MU) climbed 4% each.
In other stocks, Media General (MEG) spiked 53% after reporting it would buy print publishing and television station owner Meredith (MDP) for $3.1 billion, including debt.

The companies said the cash-and-stock deal would create the third largest local TV station owner in the U.S., to be renamed Meredith Media General. Media General has been consolidating since January 2014.
Tampa, Fla.-based utility Teco Energy (TECO) generated a 24% gain after revealing Friday it was in discussions to be acquired by Nova Scotia-based Emera in a cash deal valued near $6.48 billion.
FitBit (FIT) kicked up 7% after a Morgan Stanley report upgraded the stock to overweight, from equal weight, and boosted the stock's price target to 58 from 43.

The maker of wearable fitness tracking devices has had a wild ride since its June initial public offering, with shares ending Friday 39% below their July high, but still 59% above their June IPO price.

The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. Oil also traded mixed, with West Texas Intermediate down nearly 2% and Brent crude up more than 2%. Increase the bottom line by making cuts in departments where you spend the most money. So suggests Matthew Figgie, author of "Maximizing Profits Immediately" and chairman of Clark-Reliance, which makes liquid gauges for the oil and gas industry."Expensive software or consultants are not necessary," he told IBD. "Just an understanding and implementation of a few foundational profit improvement techniques" can make a big difference.Tips on how best to profit: Analyze. Identify which years your firm performed best in a variety of spending categories. Next, check how profit would rise if those numbers were garnered in the same 12-month period. "You'll be amazed at the yearly profit that is attainable," Figgie said. Look beyond growth. A 5% reduction in costs will more than double pretax profit, says Figgie. Buy intelligently. Purchase, don't expedite, is Figgie's point.Your purchasing department should avoid single-sourced items. Make sure that unit has the independence to be creative when negotiating with competing suppliers. Charge properly. Companies work hard to cut costs in a product's design, parts and manufacturing, then give away all their savings through poor pricing strategies.Say you manufacture a part for $10 and sell it wholesale for $20. After using profit improvement techniques, you reduce costs to $9 and use the same markup to sell the product for $18."You are giving away $2 for every dollar you save," said Figgie.He adds that thousands of small and midsize U.S. firms are profitable while competing with international competition — and don't always have to underprice "as long as they are providing their customers with a superior product." Compensate. Start thinking you can boost profit if you treat all of your stakeholders as partners. That's the view of Philip Kotler, who has studied under three Nobel laureate economists and authored "Confronting Capitalism.""Winning companies see their employees, suppliers and distributors as a working team," he said. "All of them must feel fairly rewarded." The payoff is "stakeholder-oriented companies often earn greater profits than shareholder-only rewarded companies." Boost fitness. Knowing that medical costs rise 20% per year, Jim Miller, CEO of tech platform Krowdfit, financially rewards members for healthy living."What other single cost in running your business is going up at 20% per year that you have the direct ability to influence by simply deploying an accountable wellness incentive program?" he said. "There is no better way to improve profits, individual performance and reduce costs than to improve the health of your employees." Market accordingly. Spend money to make money to increase profit through consumer awareness. Glean insights from analytics and digital marketing.Kotler recommends putting 10% of your promotion budget in blogging and social media presentations on such sites as Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), LinkedIn (LNKD) and Google (GOOGL)-owned YouTube. If you get good results, add another 10%. He adds that Procter & Gamble (PG) spends 25% to 35% of its promotion budget on digital marketing. Know the consumer. "Many companies offer similar products and deals," Kotler said. "You must not only match your competitors, but do one better. There are many coffee shops, but only one Starbucks (SBUX). Starbucks not only sells good coffee, but positions itself as a third home for its customers. Your job is to create a better life for your customers."

Stocks came out of the gate with a bang.....moving higher in the early seconds after the bell rang only to weaken as the mins ticked by......at 10:20 - the mkt was not only negative but was testing support .......and like I said in yesterday's note - it found the buyers......that's all it needed. The fact that the mkt failed to 'break' WAS the positive and it was off to the races...... By 3:30 - the indexes were once again flirting with their highs....and Nasdaq? Well that index was not only flirting, it was teasing traders and investors - daring them to push it up and thru its March 2000 high of 5048.....But alas - that was not to be yesterday.....and it may have a bit of trouble today as well....at least until investors have a chance to react to the disappointing tech numbers reported after the bell last night.

Now - let's put this in perspective....Facebook (FB) - which everyone was waiting for - did not disappoint.... Sales rose by 42%....not bad, but the afterhours crowd was looking for 49%...so those bozo's were disappointed and took 2 1/2% out of the stock in the moments following the release....Now - revenue growth was impacted by the stronger dollar - and since FB generates more than 50% of its revenue overseas - then you can see the impact that the strong dollar had....BUT we KNEW THIS.....And since they don't 'produce' a product overseas - they did not get the benefit of weaker foreign currencies like so many of the multi-nationals are getting... In the end - earnings of 42 cts were ABOVE the 40 cts expectation and well above a year ago of 35 cts.... So - get over yourself....This was not a negative report....In early pre-mkt trading - the stock is holding right in line at $83.65 - which was yesterday's low...Now on Tuesday - the stock did gap up - just a bit - so technically - it might want to go back and 'fill that gap' at $83.15......and then after that...well - I suspect it could go on to challenge the March highs of $86/sh.

Texas Instruments (TXN) and Qualcomm (QCOM) - well those are different issues - and in fact more concerning...as they missed on earnings and 'lowered forward guidance'.....So my sense is that these stocks will cause investors to focus on the negatives....causing the mkt to once again stall - for now.

Look - Earnings results so far from 110 companies reported in the S&P are on track to fall 4% from a year earlier.... The S&P is trading at 17.4 X's the previous 12 months' earnings, - this is 17% ABOVE the historical 10-yr average of 14.6 X's...... This is why the mkt has been tossing and turning of late.....We are trading above historical averages all while U.S. economic indicators continue to miss and disappoint causing long term investors to sit tight - thus the lack of real commitment and volumes......

One of the most interesting reads on this are the 'Economic Surprise Indexes' that exist across the street. Citigroup (C) has one, BB has one and both are negative as of the 20th......In fact the BB Surprise Index is making fresh lows......The index measures whether the eco data is beating or missing forecasts, and the fact that it is sitting at its lowest level since the end of the GFC (Great Financial Crisis) - should be just a bit concerning....Next week we get 1Q GDP, which we know is not going to be 'robust' , the Atlanta Fed is projecting growth of ZERO and yet here we are testing new highs. Does anyone else suspect a disconnect? Is someone 'spoofing' us?

Next week (28/29) we will hear from the FED - you can expect to hear more about a weak global economy, strong dollar, weak earnings, zero GDP growth and lack of inflation - all as reasons for caution in the months ahead.....June is OFF the table - rates not going anywhere.....August is most likely off the table as well - but they will not close that door in April......they need to keep hope alive that rates will begin the move higher......with probably no real intent on doing anything as long as the US economy continues to waffle back and forth. NY Fed Pres. Dudley had this to say:

"While I am relatively optimistic about the growth outlook for 2015, I also must acknowledge that there are some significant downside risks...in particular the 15% appreciation of the exchange value of the dollar since mid 2014 is making US exports more expensive and imports more competitive"
(The strong dollar is expected to reduce GDP growth by about 0.6%).

Speaking of 'spoofing' - have you seen the latest on the story of the week? Exchanges in both the US and Europe had this clown on 'trader watch' - identifying numerous suspicious trades over a period of months....very large orders entered and then cancelled over and over.....in '09 and '10 they even questioned his actions...telling him that on the very day of the crash that "orders are expected to be entered in good faith for the purpose of executing bona fide transactions".

How's that working for you? It wasn't until 2012 when the still unknown whistle blower identified all of these suspicious trades dated May 6th. The CFTC (Commodities Futures Trading Commission) saying that they do NOT have the technology to monitor cancelled trades in 'real time' hindering their ability to police the mkt...( you mean to tell me that technology can follow me around the world, knowing everything about me yet - we can't monitor trades in a completely electronic world?) ...Gary Gensler former head of the CFTC, former GS MD, and now Hillary's CFO for her Presidential campaign, issues a 104 page report explaining the cause of the flash crash and admits that they never even looked at spoofing, layering , manipulation or order cancellations....... You can't make this up...who would believe it?

US futures are down 5 pts at 2094......as we await some big earnings today...Companies reporting during the day include 3M (MMM), CAT (CAT), GM (GM), PEP (PEP), PG (PG), United Continental (UAL)......After the bell we will hear from Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOGL), MSFT (MSFT) and Capital One (COF). Eco data today is more housing data....new home sales of are expected to be down 4.5%....in contrast to yesterday surprise 6% rise in existing home sales....so more confusion......In addition we will get Init Jobless Claims of 287K, Cont Claims of 2.29 mil and the Kansas City Fed Manf report of -2.
Support for the S&P is now at 2085.....Look for the mkt to test is today's numbers show signs of disappointment.

In Europe - mkts are lower.....Eurozone business activity disappoints....Markits Flash PMI fell to 53.5 from 54......German PMI fell to 54.2 form 55.4.....(remember a read above 50 is expansionary - so it is not a complete disaster - but the trend is moving in the wrong direction) Spanish unemployment rose and UK retail sales fell......FTSE +0.08%, CAC 40 - 0.77%, DAX - 1.06%, EUROSTOXX -0.94%, SPAIN -0.72% and ITALY -0.73%.

In Asia - Chinese Flash PMI fell to 49.2 vs. the est of 49.6 (below 50 is contractionary) but markets are shrugging off the news as it raises expectations of MORE stimulus. Japan +0.27%, Hong Kong -0.38%, China +0.4% and ASX +0.12%

In case you missed it - Carly Fiorina is throwing her name in the ring as a Republican candidate for Pres.......on May 4th...and then she will be one of the keynote speakers at the May 5 TECHCRUNCH DISRUPT NY conference. She is also launching her book on that day as well as appearing across the range of cable programs..... Carly Fiorina - really? How would she deal with Putin, Iran, Syria, Hamas, ISIS, Yemen, and Iraq....to name just a few of the int'l challenges that confront the US president... She was the CEO at HP (HPQ)!
Take good care.

Procter & Gamble (PG) might be looking to sell some of its beauty brands, but who's buying? A few of them could be attractive to Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH), says one analyst.

P&G is already the beauty product retailer's largest supplier, said Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow in a Thursday note. Two brands in particular could be tempting for Sally Beauty: hair color brands Wella Color Charm and Clairol Professional.
Combined, they generate about $200 million in annual retail sales, with $150 million just through Sally Beauty, he points out.
Acquiring one or more P&G brands would be "highly accretive" to Sally Beauty's margins, as it could raise prices after it becomes the sole distributor of a particular product.
Shares of both companies were down 0.4% in the stock market today.

P&G, which is shedding many of its other brands, is reportedly exploring a possible sale or IPO of its beauty portfolio. Boruchow said Revlon (REV), Unilever (UN) and Coty (COTY) are a few other names being tossed around as potential buyers and could sell off subsets of P&G beauty brands.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

William Procter, who with fellow immigrant James Gamble founded the consumer product giant Procter & Gamble in 1837, always took the long view.One of the strengths of P&G (PG) over the past two centuries has been long-range planning, a trait inherited from its earliest days.A reason for Procter's stress on the future may well have been that his early days were daunting.Procter (1801-84) started out with plenty of hardship that he overcame, says Ed Rider, retired head of P&G's corporate archives.Born in Herefordshire in western England, Procter became a general store apprentice during his youth and learned a skill, candle-making, that helped in hard times and was the earliest growth engine at P&G.The tough times started just as Procter opened a dry goods shop in London in 1831. On Day 2 it was robbed and set on fire.Off To OhioIn debt and looking for better prospects, 31-year-old Procter and his wife, Martha, set out for the American West, where many immigrants prospered. They got as far as Cincinnati when she caught cholera and died.Thinking of her death and his debt, he took a job in a bank. But the brisk growth of his adopted city sparked his entrepreneurial flame. With his candle-making skills in demand, he left the bank and built a firm making the tallow product.Procter was an obscure tradesman in a crowd of entrepreneurs at the gateway to the American West. He knew that to prosper, he had to adapt and grow with the quickly changing scene.Cincinnati was a hub of trade in the 1830s. It prospered from river transport and livestock and other farm markets. For small shops like Procter's, it was a source of needed raw materials like fat and oil used in making candles.Procter made sure to place his factory-store near the Ohio River for easy access to supplies and movement to markets. Meanwhile, he shifted from artisan to merchant — and married again, this time to Olivia Norris, daughter of another candle maker.Before long, the Panic of 1837 sank many banks and the economy, hurting many small businesses such as Procter's. His father-in-law, Alexander Norris, wanted to see his young relatives survive the crisis. So he suggested that Procter combine his operations with those of James Gamble, a soap maker who married Olivia's sister Elizabeth in 1837.Both of the younger men used similar raw materials that came from the area's stockyards. They proceeded to scale up their operations as other businesses lost out.Procter and Gamble also put over $7,000 into the combined works to recapitalize.As the economy turned around, these funds helped the firm , which made soap and candles and related products such as household oil, grow faster than its competition. Procter & Gamble persisted as a partnership until it was incorporated in 1890."The importance of making strategic decisions like that was recognized very early," Charlotte Otto, a former global relations officer at P&G and now senior corporate strategist at the public relations firm Weber Shandwick, told IBD.Later, P&G leaders often referred to that "heritage of looking ahead at the implications of change and the dynamics of markets, and taking action early," she said.Procter and teammate Gamble divided the firm's functions, with sales and accounting under the former, and manufacturing connected to the latter.Procter's grasp of detail kept this process in motion and formed the base for P&G's planning. As America's industry, economy and personal income grew over the next few decades, so did demand for P&G's consumable goods.The new railroad of the 1830s opened the way for market expansion. Procter took advantage by sending his son George to New York, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Chicago to prospect for new customers.Up to then, P&G was making 100 to 120 boxes of soap a day, and 50 to 75 boxes of candles.Stacking 'Em UpThanks to George's long-distance work, orders flooded in for 1,000 to 2,000 boxes a day, requiring larger equipment and bigger payrolls.As America's stockyards and railroads grew with more investment for new processes and equipment, so did the P&G enterprise.P&G improved its manufacturing process and built its soap, candle and oil products into brands that customers came to know for reliability and quality.The firm started using a moon and stars logo, a form of which still exists, on its packaging in 1851 to set itself apart from commodities — and in 1859, P&G's annual sales passed $1 million (worth $30 million now) for the first time.U.S. businesses knew the Civil War was coming and foresaw disruption. Few planned as well as P&G, which in the early 1860s built a new plant in Cincinnati to deal with growth they saw coming during and after the war. But they were challenged .In 1862 the firm won a contract with the Union Army to supply soap and candles. This kept P&G's factories running amid the Civil War.Procter and Gamble faced a huge take: getting raw materials. What paid off was their top training of the next generation. Their sons James Norris Gamble and William Alexander Procter raced off to New Orleans and bought a boatload of vital pine rosin. Their rivals laughed, thinking they had overbought, but this supply lasted nearly to war's end in 1865 — while P&G dominated its markets.Cleaning UpP&G ran out of other raw materials, like stearic acid , a byproduct from slaughterhouses that was used in making soap. But the company developed a new way to synthesize the acid. This process would be adapted years later by P&G to make Crisco, the first all-vegetable shortening.When pine rosin supplies ran out near the end of the war, P&G substituted silicate of soda. Later, this became a key component of its soap and detergent."The diversification from soap to food and edibles like Crisco was followed by the development of detergents," Rider said. "And you had to have new equipment for all the nonsoap cleaning products."P&G had to shift even more dramatically after the candle business peaked in 1867. First petroleum-based oil, then the light bulb, snuffed out the wax product.By that year, market leader P&G had a number of growing rivals, including Colgate-Palmolive."So it became a matter of if P&G didn't do it first, someone else would have," said Rider.Procter lived long enough to see the first major advertising campaign for a P&G product, Ivory Soap. He was not a great believer in ads, but they gave a boost to the company's painstaking product planning and development.P&G's business philosophy endured as a family tradition until the 1970s. The two generations following Procter served as successive presidents and CEOs, and his business philosophy was conveyed by William Cooper Procter's handpicked successor, Richard Deupree, who had an office at the headquarters until 1972. Their emphasis on product quality and value, fair treatment of customers, suppliers and employees descended from the founders, Otto says.Here's the payoff for investors: In "Eyes on Tomorrow: The Evolution of Procter & Gamble," Oscar Schisgall describes the original capital of publicly traded P&G as $4.5 million of stock on July 17, 1890. Since then, P&G's market cap has grown to $225 billion.The steady company's stock has risen 200% since 2000.

Stock indexes were having trouble getting past the starting gate Friday afternoon. The Nasdaq gripped a 0.1% gain, while the S&P 500 was flat and the Dow Jones industrial average slouched 0.2%. Volume rose from the previous session's pace.E-signature and authentication products provider Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) surged 3% in volume about 50% above average. The small-cap stock first cleared a 28.27 buy point Wednesday and then dipped under the entry Thursday. Now it's back above the buy point.Vasco carries a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99, but the company's five-year earnings Stability Factor is 37 on a scale that runs from a calm 0 to a wild 99. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into a single number. A rating of 99 means the stock is in the top 1 percentile.Among big caps, eBay (EBAY) popped 1% in heavy volume as it made a new, 52-week high. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base May 29, clearing a 60.24 buy point. The cup-with-handle is a bullish pattern. Ebay was No. 19 in Tuesday's Big Cap 20, a computer-generated list of the best big caps by fundamentals and technicals.Other top price performers Friday afternoon included the super-regional banks. Several stocks in the group were threatening to cross buy points, including SunTrust Banks (STI), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and BB&T (BBT). The fundamentals of the super regional banks, however, are spotty.Follow Paul Whitfield on Twitter: @IBD_PWhitfield.

Stocks fell in mixed volume Tuesday as sellers stepped forward aggressively for the first time in almost two weeks.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each trimmed 0.7%, while the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3%.
Volume was running higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq. However, Nasdaq volume had picked up and was approaching the break-even line.

Blue chips were mostly down in the stock market today. On the Dow, the biggest percentage gainer was Procter & Gamble (PG), which thrust 1% to a new high in heavy volume. The company recently settled a patent infringement lawsuit over P&G's tooth-whitening strips. Terms were not revealed, but Clio USA agreed to quit making the products involving P&G's patents.

The biggest loser in the Dow was JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which fell 2% in fast trade. The bank announced that the Department of Justice opened a criminal investigation into JPMorgan's foreign exchange business.

Among highly rated stocks, chip designer Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 5% in heavy volume. There was no news, but Ambarella had risen 36% in 15 sessions after a staging a U-turn at the 50-day moving average. The small-cap company's chips are for security and surveillance applications and are in GoPro's (GPRO) wearable cameras.
GoPro was up 1% after rising 30% in five sessions.
Selling after fast gains is normal action. And with the U.S. voting in the midterm elections today, investors have a reason to hold off buying stocks until they get clarity.

In economic news, factory orders for September fell 0.6%, a little better than the 0.7% dip expected. The International Council of Shopping Centers reported same-store sales dropped 1.6% for the week after rising 0.3% in the prior week.Stocks fell in mixed volume Tuesday as sellers stepped forward aggressively for the first time in almost two weeks.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each trimmed 0.7%, while the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3%.Volume was running higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq. However, Nasdaq volume had picked up and was approaching the break-even line.Blue chips were mostly down in the stock market today. On the Dow, the biggest percentage gainer was Procter & Gamble (PG), which thrust 1% to a new high in heavy volume. The company recently settled a patent infringement lawsuit over P&G's tooth-whitening strips. Terms were not revealed, but Clio USA agreed to quit making the products involving P&G's patents.The biggest loser in the Dow was JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which fell 2% in fast trade. Tech titan Google (GOOGL) will make headlines with its quarterly earnings after the close on Thursday. But Google's growth is sluggish and the stock is lackluster. Check out these five stocks with better performance than the search giant, including drugmaker AbbVie (ABBV) and coffee giant Starbucks (SBUX).
Alexion, AbbVie Drug Earnings

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) is projected to see earnings decline by 13% to $1.33 a share when it reports its first-quarter results before the open. But that's a blip rather than a trend. Earnings rose 53%, 53% and 49% in the prior three quarters and should rise more than 20% in each of the following three quarters.
Revenue is estimated to rise 4.4% to $591 million.

The biotech has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of 99. Its only product currently on shelves is rare-disease drug Soliris, which has seen blockbuster success. Analysts estimate that the company's asfotase alfa drug will launch in the first half of the year. Alexion may provide an update.
Alexion shares rose 0.8% to 188.19 on the stock market today. The stock is working on a price consolidation with a 203.40 buy point.
AbbVie (ABBV) also releases its Q1 results before the open. The ethical drugmaker is expected to increase earnings by 20% to 85 cents a share. That's faster than Q4's 9% growth.
Wall Street has calculated a 9.2% rise in revenue to $4.982 billion.

Earlier this month, Galapagos, a Belgian biotech partnered with AbbVie, reported positive midstage data for its rheumatoid-arthritis drug filgotinib as an add-on to the standard treatment, methotrexate. AbbVie has the best-selling treatment for that condition, the injectable drug Humira.

This will be the first full quarter of sales for hepatitis C treatment, Viekira Pak. How successful was AbbVie in grabbing market share from first-to-market Gilead Sciences' (GILD) Sovaldi and Harvoni? AbbVie and Gilead Sciences have made price discounts with top pharmacy benefit managers.

Analysts also will be interested in AbbVie's planned $21 billion deal for Pharmacyclics (PCYC), maker of blockbuster blood cancer drug Imbruvica. Many on Wall Street think AbbVie is paying a steep price.
AbbVie shares rose 1.4% to 64.52 Wednesday. It's working on the right side of a cup base with a 70.86 buy point. The drugmaker has an IBD Composite Rating of 90 out of 99.
Alaska, Southwest Airlines On Earnings Takeoff

Alaska Air (ALK) is expected to report a 72% jump in Q1 earnings to $1.10 per share when it reports Thursday morning. That would mark a second quarter of faster growth. Revenue is seen rising by a more-modest 3.9% to $1.27 billion.
The domestic regional airline is benefiting from lower fuel prices, strong pricing power and improving demand for travel.
Alaska shares fell 1% to 64.31 Wednesday, and are working on a flat base with a 71.50 buy point. Alaska has a 92 Composite Rating.

Southwest Airlines (LUV), which has a 91 Composite Rating, is set to report its Q1 results Thursday morning. Earnings are expected to surge 261% to 65 cents a share, a huge acceleration from last quarter's 79% growth. Revenue is seen increasing 6% to $4.415 billion.
Earlier this month, the Dallas-based airline, which only has international flights to Mexico and the Caribbean, reported a 6.7% jump in March traffic and a 4.4% increase in capacity.
Southwest shares are building a flat base with a 47.27 buy point. Southwest stock fell 0.4% to 42.85 on Wednesday.
Starbucks Sales Growth Perking Up

Starbucks reports fiscal Q2 results after the close. Wall Street expects earnings to grow by 17.9% to 33 cents a share, up from 14% year-over-year growth in Q1. Revenue is seen rising 16.9% to $4.53 billion. That would mark Starbucks' fastest sales growth in several years.

The coffee giant has been at the forefront of restaurant tech, from its loyalty card to its mobile app, which Starbucks says has 13 million active users. The company is also testing a mobile order-and-pay function and a delivery program.

Starbucks, which has a 94 Composite Rating, fell 3 cents to 48.33 Wednesday. The stock extended 15% past a flat base buy point of 42.20, which it initially cleared in late January. Investors who bought the stock in buy range should take profits at a 20% to 25% gain.
Other big-name companies releasing quarterly earnings on Thursday include Amazon.com (AMZN),Microsoft (MSFT), Altria (MO),General Motors (GM), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Dow Chemical (DOW).

Currency headwinds hit yet another earnings report, as Tiffany's  (TIF) holiday-quarter results and outlook were dragged down by the strong dollar, prompting one analyst to slash his price target. Tiffany's net sales decreased 1% to $1.29 billion on foreign exchange woes, falling short of forecasts for $1.31 billion and marking the first revenue loss in five years. Earnings growth…

Procter & Gamble (PG) is said to be exploring a potential sale or initial public offering of some of its beauty brands, said Bloomberg News.Shares were still up 1.8% in early afternoon trading following the news in the stock market today, Monday. CoverGirl, Pantene, Olay and Old Spice are just a few of the company's 34 beauty brands.Procter & Gamble is working with advisers but has not finalized any details nor pinpointed specific beauty brands, said Bloomberg, citing sources familiar with the matter, and P&G may not necessarily go through with the separation.The beauty segment brought in 24% of the company's total 2014 net sales of $83.1 billion. Segment sales dipped 2% to $19.5 billion for the year and global beauty market share edged down 0.4 percentage points vs. 2013, said Procter & Gamble in its annual report. The consumer products giant's non-beauty offerings include Pampers, Gillette and Swiffer.The company announced last August that it would shave off more than 100 brands by mid-2016, opting to keep its 70-80 most profitable brands that make up nearly 90% of sales.In late January, shares gapped down more than 3% as the global company said the strong dollar would affect full-year outlook, with sales cut by 5% and net earnings impacted by 12% as a result. Foreign exchange woes have hurt many American companies that bring in overseas sales, ranging from Apple (AAPL) to Priceline (PCLN) to Pfizer (PFE).But Procter & Gamble remains a top dividend stock in the eyes of many, as shares continue to climb back toward their 200-day and 50-day lines.RELATED:James Gamble Cleaned Up With P&G Household Products.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Tuesday as an analyst warning on the new Apple iPhone hurt shares of the company and its suppliers.The Nasdaq was off 0.6% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.2%.Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq. Declining stocks had a small edge over advancers on the NYSE while the losers led by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Solar energy, automaker, staffing and dairy product companies were among the poorest performers in the stock market today. Tesla (TSLA) skidded more than 3%, sinking deeper below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Metal, retail, utility and real estate investment trust industry groups were some of the best Tuesday.Some suppliers of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone were lower after Credit Suisse warned that the company was cutting back component orders for the iPhone 6S model.Apple shares gapped down to a 3% loss in above-average volume. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 7% in busy trading and fell below the 50-day moving average. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) gapped below its 50-day moving average as it shed 6% in heavy trading.On the plus side, Ruth's Hospitality (RUTH), better known as Ruth's Chris Steak House, cleared the 16.96 buy point of a double-bottom base in active trading.The company beat Q3 earnings expectations a couple of weeks ago as EPS jumped 33%. The restaurant industry group, though, has been trending lower in IBD's group rankings.

Stocks ended off their session highs Thursday but still rallied sharply. Several key stocks moved after the close on earnings reports.The Nasdaq ended with a 1.6% gain after being up as much as 2.1%. It hit resistance at its 50-day line. The S&P 500 finished up 1.2%, down from 1.8% at Thursday's high. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.3%. According to preliminary data, volume ended mixed in the stock market today: NYSE trade edged up, but Nasdaq volume fell.After the close, Amazon.com (AMZN) slumped 9% after missing views. The e-commerce giant reported a Q3 loss of 95 cents a share on sales of $20.5 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a loss of 74 cents a share on revenue of $20.84 billion.Juniper Networks (JNPR) slumped 5% on disappointing guidance for Q4 earnings. The company also announced the expansion of a plan to return capital to shareholders.GoPro (GPRO) fell 2% after Oppenheimer started cover with an underperform rating an a 45 price target. The stock had already lost 1% in the regular session.Microsoft (MSFT) was one bright spot after hours. It rallied 3% after beating views on both earnings and sales.Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY), Colgate-Palmolive (CL), Moody's Investors Service (MCO), Procter & Gamble (PG) and United Parcel Service (UPS) are among some notable companies reporting quarterly results Friday. Data on September new-home sales will also be out Friday.
Stocks opened lower but quickly turned mixed in quiet trade early Friday, with chip stocks under particularly heavy pressure.

The Dow Jones industrial average managed a 0.1% gain, as Procter & Gamble (PG), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Coca-Cola (KO) all gained more than 1%. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2%. The Nasdaq spun lower, losing 0.8%. Volume was very weak, down 90% on the Nasdaq and 89% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Thursday.

A volatile premarket session might have hinted at what kind of trade investors can expect from the stock market today . Futures dug deep into losses in early trade, shadowing heavy sell-offs across Europe and Asia. Futures then abruptly trimmed losses and turned mixed, with Dow and S&P 500 futures rising just before the start of regular trade.
Chipmakers got slammed at the open, however, with Intel's (INTC) 4% loss holding back the Dow. The worst loss among Nasdaq 100 stocks was an 11% dive by Netherlands-based NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).
Leading stocks staged a surprisingly positive open, with three in five IBD 50 stocks rising in early trade.

But Avago Technologies (AVGO), the hardest hit among IBD 50 stocks, toppled 10% in heavy trade. The slide put the Singapore-based chip developer well below its 10-week line of support and left it just even with a 72.60 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Chipmaker Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) skittered 7% lower. The stock had been fighting to regain its 50-day moving average in a shallow consolidation, but Friday's gap-down loss sent shares 18% below their Sept. 25 high.
Tesla Motors (TSLA) slumped 6% in very heavy trade. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based automaker on Thursday evening introduced the "D," an all-wheel drive version of its Model S sedan.

On the upside, generic-drug maker Lannett (LCI) climbed 2%, edging closer to the buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened lower but quickly turned mixed in quiet trade early Friday, with chip stocks under particularly heavy pressure.The Dow Jones industrial average managed a 0.1% gain, as Procter & Gamble (PG), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Coca-Cola (KO) all gained more than 1%. Those are all good readings. However, of the 11 stocks in the group, none is high profile names in the current stock market. Are there any…
Coach (COH) signed an 11-year global licensing agreement with Interparfums for fragrances, walking away from its Estee Lauder (EL) partnership after nine years.

Interparfums will create, produce and distribute new fragrances and related products for men and women. Coach retail stores will carry the Interparfums-made products in the fall of 2016, and its fragrances will be distributed to department, specialty and duty-free stores worldwide.
Interparfums already has several large fragrance brands under its umbrella, including Jimmy Choo, Lanvin and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF).
Coach shares edged up 0.1% in the stock market today. The stock has been building a flat base for the past month.

The company, mainly known for its handbags, has been undergoing a brand makeover as it tries to recapture shoppers that have increasingly moved on to brands such as Michael Kors (KORS), Kate Spade (KATE) and Tory Burch. Estee Lauder has fragrance licensing deals with Kors and Tory Burch.
"We look forward to developing new fragrances that capture the spirit of the Coach brand and to taking the portfolio to a larger audience," said Interparfums CEO Philippe Benacin in a statement.

"With our distribution network, we have a great opportunity to build upon the success already seen with Coach fragrance by expanding the distribution globally and by capitalizing on the growing recognition of the brand in international markets."

Interparfums said last month that it would acquire Rochas, a fashion house and perfume brand, from Procter & Gamble (PG) in a deal worth $108 million. P&G has been shedding a number of its businesses, with some analysts speculating that Sally Beauty (SBH) is a good candidate to buy some of its beauty brands.
